translated: Basket of Conduct
The Chapter of Akitti
The Perfection of Generosity
The Story of Akitti
Homage to that Blessed One, the Worthy One, the Rightly Self-awakened One.
“For a hundred thousand eons,
and for four incalculable eons;
In that time, whatever was practiced,
all of that ripened for awakening.
In past lives, whatever was practiced,
except for birth and death;
In this eon, whatever was practiced,
I will tell, listen to me.
When I was in the great forest,
in an empty wilderness grove;
Having entered and dwelt,
I was an ascetic named Akitti.

analyzed: tadā mam tapa tejena  santattaḥ tidiva abhibhū
translated: Then, with the splendor of my austerities,🔽the one who surpasses the gods of the Thirty-three;
Bearing the form of a brahmin,
he approached me for alms.
Having brought a leaf from the forest,
without oil and salt;
Seeing it placed at my door,
I took it with my hand.
Having given him the leaf,🔽and turning over the vessel;
Having abandoned the search,
I entered the leaf hut.
For a second and a third time,
he came into my presence;
Unshaken and unmoved,
I gave in this way.
I have no regret for my body,
because of that giving;
I spent that day in rapture and joy.
If for a month or two months

analyzed: dakkhiṇeyyam varam labhe  a kampitaḥ an olīnaḥ
translated: I could get a worthy recipient,🔽I would give the supreme gift,

analyzed: dadeyyam dānam uttama  na tassa dānam dadamānaḥ
translated: unwavering and unperturbed.🔽When I gave that gift,
I did not seek fame or gain;
Seeking omniscience,
I performed those deeds.”
The Story of Akitti, the First.
